pageData.text: Archerfish have an interesting mechanism for hunting their prey. As the name implies, they “shoot” at their prey by spitting powerful jets of water out of their mouths at insects on leaves above the water. The jets are typically extremely accurate and knock the insects off of their leaves and into the waiting mouths of the archerfish.  However, since the archerfish is shooting from underwater, it must account for the refractive index of the water in aiming at the insects.  Since water bends the light, an insect on a leaf will not actually be where it appears to be through the layers of water. Humans actually have the same problem when trying to catch fish under the surface of the water. However, the archerfish is specially adapted to this method of hunting and is able to minimize the distortion caused by the refraction of light through water. The placement of the fish’s eyes and its body shape allow it to swim directly underneath the insect and get close to the surface of the water without being seen by its prey. These two factors minimize the bending of light and allow the fish to hit their target<sup>1</sup>.

pageData.text: Many optical devices, including eyeglasses, microscopes, and telescopes, depend on the refraction, or bending, of light as light passes from one medium to another. As light travels through different media, the speed and sometimes the direction of the rays of light change. The degree to which the light is refracted can be predicted by a mathematical equation called <button class='glossary-text'>Snell’s law</button>.

When rays of light meet an interface of two media at an angle, the light bends due to this change in speed. To better understand how this occurs, imagine a shopping cart rolling across a paved surface. When the cart transitions onto a grassy surface at an angle, one of the front wheels enters the grass before the other wheels and slows down. At the same time, the remaining wheels, still on the pavement, continue at their original speed. The cart turns toward the wheel that entered the grass first. As the remaining wheels enter the grass, their speed slows to match the first wheel until all four wheels are moving at the slower speed. In the same manner, as light moves forward, wave fronts may meet an interface between two media at an angle. If light passes into a medium that is denser, as when light travels from air to glass, the speed of light slows down. If light passes into a medium that is less dense, the speed of light increases. In both cases, if the light enters the medium at an angle other than perpendicular to the medium’s surface, the light will be refracted. A straw in a glass of water appears bent because light bends as it enters the water.

pageData.text: The angle at which light bends as it passes through different media is measured from an imaginary line that is perpendicular to the interface between the media. This line is called the <button class='glossary-text'>normal line</button>, or sometimes just “the normal.” We use “the normal line” here because the boundary between the media is sometimes curved, such as the interface between the air and a curved piece of glass. In this case, the normal line is perpendicular to the <button class='glossary-text'>tangent line</button>, which is a line that touches the curve at one point.

pageData.text: The angle through which the light changes depends on the materials and the angle at which the light strikes the interface; these angles can be determined using the refractive indices of the materials. Different materials have different indices of refraction. The index of refraction, n, is the ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum to the speed of light in the medium.

pageData.desc: Equation 1: n = c divided by v
pageData.altText: Equation 1: n = c divided by v

pageData.text: where: n = the index of refraction c = the speed of light in a vacuum (186,000 miles per second or 300,000 kilometers per second) v = the speed of light in the medium

Because the index of refraction is the ratio of two speeds, it is a dimensionless number. Although the index of refraction can be determined experimentally, the refractive indices of common materials can be readily found in tables in various resources. The refractive indices of several common materials are listed in Table 1.

pageData.desc: Equation 2: n sub 1 Times sin Theta sub 1 = n sub 2 Times Theta n θ sub 2
pageData.altText: Equation 2: n sub 1 Times sin Theta sub 1 = n sub 2 Times Theta n θ sub 2

pageData.text: where: n1 is the refractive index of the first medium, and θ1 is the angle between the ray traveling through the first medium and the . n 2 is the refractive index of the second medium, and θ2 is the angle between the ray of light traveling through the second medium and the normal line.

Consider the diagram in Figure 2 as an example. The area outside the rectangle represents medium 1, and the area inside the rectangle represents medium 2. In this example, medium 1 will be air, and medium 2 will be a block of crown glass.

The red arrow in Figure 2 is a ray of light traveling from the air into the crown glass and back into the air. The dotted lines are <button class='glossary-text'>normal lines</button>. The normal lines are imaginary lines drawn perpendicular to the boundary between the media at the point where the ray of light crosses the boundary. When the ray of light enters the block, the direction of the ray bends toward the normal line because the crown glass is a denser medium than air and decreases the speed of the light ray. When the ray of light passes from the block of glass back into the air, the ray of light bends away from the normal line due to moving from a denser medium to a less dense medium. Notice that the ray of light leaving the block of glass is traveling parallel to the ray of light entering the glass.

pageData.text: If the angles θ1 and θ2 are known, the refractive index of the glass can be calculated using .
Here is an example calculation using the following information to calculate the refractive index of this block of crown glass.

θ1 = 45° n1 (air) = 1 θ2 = 28° n 2 (crown glass) = ____________________ Solution: n1 sin θ1 = n 2 sin θ2 Snell’s law: n 2 = n1 sin θ1 / sin θ2 Solving for n 2: n 2 = (1) (sin 45°) / (sin 28°) n 2 = 1.51
This result falls within the range listed for crown glass in <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button>.
Note: The angles used in Snell’s law are always measured between the ray of light and the .

Snell’s law can be used to calculate the refractive index of a material or identify the material by determining its index of refraction. In this activity, you will use a semicircular refraction dish filled with water and other materials to calculate the refractive index of water.

pageData.text: Print or draw the Data Sheet found in Resources.
Attach the <button class='resource-text'>data sheet</button> to the piece of cardboard using staples in each of the four corners.
Place the cardboard with the data sheet facing up on a smooth, level surface. You will need to be able to look horizontally across the surface of the cardboard.

Place the refraction dish on the paper so that the flat side of the dish is aligned with the horizontal line running through the center of the paper. The dish should cover the outline of the dish drawn on the lower half of the paper but not the lines with the arrows indicating the various angles.
Fill the dish with tap water.
Place one pin at the center of the flat side of the dish, where the lines on the data sheet cross. This is point p 2 (see Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Diagram showing relationship between the semicircular dish and normal. The eye looks through the arch, and a pin is placed at P3 where it is visually aligned with P1 and P2
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Diagram showing relationship between the semicircular dish and normal. The eye looks through the arch, and a pin is placed at P3 where it is visually aligned with P1 and P2

pageData.text: Place another pin on the 10° line about 3 cm away from p 2. This is point p1 (see Figure 3). The arrows on this line indicate the direction of light traveling from medium 1 (air) into medium 2 (water).
Look through the curved side of the dish at p 2 so that your line of sight is parallel to the cardboard.
Change your viewing position right or left along the curved side of the dish until the two pins, as seen through the water, align.
Place a third pin in the cardboard along the curved side of the dish so that it aligns with the images of p1 and p 2 as seen through the water. This is point p 3 (see Figure 3).

Note: If you look over the water across the top of the dish, the pins will not be aligned. However, if you are in the correct position viewing p1 and p 2 through the water, the light will refract such that the image of the pins will align.
Remove the dish from the paper, careful to avoid spilling water.
Use a fine mechanical pencil and a ruler to draw a line connecting p1 and p 2.
Draw a second line connecting p 2 and p 3.

Using a protractor, measure the angle between the p1-p 2 line and the . The normal line is the vertical line on the paper that is perpendicular to the flat side of the dish. This is angle θ1. Record this value in Data Table 1.
Using a protractor, measure the angle between the p 2-p 3 line and the normal line. This is angle θ2. Record this value in Data Table 1.
Replace the dish on the paper. Repeat Steps 7–15 for angles 20°, 30°, 40°, 50°, 60°, 70°, and 80° (see Figure 4). Record your data in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Photo showing full experimental layout, including data sheet, protractor, and refraction dish
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Photo showing full experimental layout, including data sheet, protractor, and refraction dish

pageData.text: Calculate sin θ1 and sin θ2 for each initial angle. Most scientific calculators can calculate the sin of a given angle. Record each of these values in Data Table 1.

Calculate n2 for each angle. Substituting a value of 1 for n1, the refractive index of air, simplifies in this case to: sin θ1 = n2 sin θ2 n2 = sin θ1 / sin θ2 Record the value of n2 for each angle in Data Table 1. This is the experimental value of the refractive index of water.
Calculate the percent error between your experimental value for the refractive index of water and the known refractive index of water found in .

pageData.text: Note: When using the semicircular dish, the light is refracted when it enters the center of the flat side of the dish but will not refract again when it exits the circular surface. This is because no refraction occurs when light changes media along the normal line. For a circle, the normal line can be any line that passes through the center because all such lines will exit the circle at an angle perpendicular to the circle. Thus, in this experiment, the beam of light that enters the dish through the center of the flat side, p 2, and exits the curved side is traveling along a normal line and will not refract again on reentering the air.
